Award.AwardTitle: The NBC2: Growing a Regional and National Bioeconomy, One Locale at a Time

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Biomanufacturing is one of the few manufacturing industries that continues to expand in spite of downturns in the national and global economy. Biopharmaceuticals and biofuels are among the bioproducts manufactured in cellular factories in this new, advanced technology, STEM-rich industry.

This project continues the center activities in order to continue to encourage the creation of additional biomanufacturing programs throughout the nation to support a growing biopharmaceutical, biofuels, regenerative medicine, and bioproducts industry, that is, the bioeconomy. In addition, it expands the NBC2 curricular materials, adding additional biofuels and new stem cell hands-on laboratories, virtual industrial biomanufacturing production modules in partnership with the world's largest contract biomanufacturer, and an online lecture series to be used to accompany hands-on laboratories in biomanufacturing courses. The project also is experimenting with flexible packaging of NBC2 curricular modules to allow customization of courses for various audiences (high school, community college, university, student graduates and incumbent workers) and time frames. It is building a "Course in a Box" for many modules in order to provide access to the materials and supplies needed to teach each module. Public understanding of biomanufacturing career paths is enhanced through the expansion of a career website at www.biomanufacturingcareers.org. The NBC2 is working to offer a National Association of Manufacturing-endorsed biomanufacturing technician certification. The project is documenting and publicizing details about career paths of students using web-based data analysis that tracks students and shows trends in industry. The Center expects to apply for non-profit status to sustain the center after NSF ATE funding.

The intellectual merit of the project includes: 1) generation of a complete suite of curriculum products using different pedagogical approaches to teach biopharmaceutical, biofuels and other crossover biomanufacturing fields, including hands-on laboratories, textbooks, online lectures with online ancillary support. In addition, the project is developing virtual biomanufacturing equipment and processes to teach, assess and practice troubleshooting; 2) availability of these products in many different formats, including traditional print or online for use by diverse populations of students; 3) a career path that includes high school, community college, biomanufacturing experience, and a career in biomanufacturing; and 4) use of a web-based data analysis tools to track student career paths and show trends in industry.

The broader impacts of the proposal include: 1) creation of a national network of self-sustaining local infrastructures for biomanufacturing education and training, and the workforce to support a growing bioeconomy; 2) institutionalization of biomanufacturing education and training courses and programs; 3) continued development of new instructional materials to grow and enhance current offerings; 4) a biomanufacturing certification exam endorsed by the National Association of Manufacturers; 5) data collected on biomanufacturing career paths and the bioeconomy; and 6) formation of a non-profit entity to sell products and services which in time will support NBC2 functions of growing partners, mentoring programs, promoting biomanufacturing career paths, updating curricular offerings, and providing professional development opportunities for students, faculty, teachers and technicians.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NBC2: Growing a Regional and National Bioeconomy, One Locale at a Time

The Northeast Biomanufacturing Center and Collaborative (NBC2) based at Montgomery County Community College (MCCC) in Blue Bell, PA, is committed to developing curriculum resources and training to prepare an advanced technological workforce to support a rapidly growing biomanufacturing industry. NBC2 consists of six hubs, located at community colleges across the nation, each of which develops a local network of biopharmaceutical companies, educational institutions, and trade organizations. The six Hub are centered at the following institutions:

  • BigPharma Hub at MCCC and Bucks County Community College;
  • New England Hub at Mount Wachusetts Community College, Devens, MA;
  • Upstate New York Hub at Finger Lakes Community College in Canandaigua, NY
  • Southern Hub at Alamance Community College in Graham, NC;
  • Midwest Hub at Ivy Tech Community College in Bloomington, IN; 
  • Western Hub at Miracosta College in Oceanside, CA.

 

Major Accomplishments

Partnerships

There are now greater than 100 educational institutions providing biomanufacturing education and training in the U.S. NBC2 has mentored and partnered with many biotechnology programs to add or update biomanufacturing components due to the maturation of the biopharmaceutical industry in their location, including:

 

Quincy College,MA

Hagerstown Community College, MD

Onondaga Community College, NY

San Jacinto College, CA

Santa Ana College, CA

Roxbury Community College, MA

Erie Community College, NY

Blinn College, Bryant, TX

NCTM, Texas A&M, College Station, TX

Citrus College, Glendora, CA

LA Valley College in Los Angeles, CA

LA Trade Tech in Los Angeles, CA

Kansas City College, KS

Hatboro Horsham High School, Horsham PA

Middlesex County Community College, NJ

 

Curriculum

Through the many partnerships within the biomanufacturing industry and associated industry organizations NBC2 has developed a suite of industry endorsed curriculum materials for technician training. Collaboration with nine biomanufacturing companies resulted in the development of the first Introduction to Biomanufacturing textbook written by industry subject matter experts and released in 2012. An updated and expanded second edition was released in 2015. This edition contained a new unit entitled Manufacture of Drug Product consisting of three new chapters on this important area of biopharmaceutical manufacture. To improve access to this text and to support the movement towards low or no cost instructional materials for students NBC2 recently made the textbook freely available to students and faculty through the NBC2 website.

A wide range of other curricular material including lab modules and manuals, standard operating procedures and other training resources, can also be accessed and downloaded for free at the updated and expanded NBC2 website - www.biomanufacturing.org. Information on NBC2 professional development events and biomanufacturing careers and industry news can also be accessed at the site.

 

NBC2 has developed a biomanufacturing certification exam which will provide students with a credential demonstrating in depth knowledge of the field.

This project involved:

  • updating Biomanufacturing skill standards, first developed in 2008, the updated in 2013 by industry representatives
  • surveying 70 biomanufacturing technicians to determine the skills and knowledge used on the job
  • developing a test blueprint based on the survey
  • developing 300 test questions with the final version of the exam will be available in January of 2017

 

Curriculum/Publications

  1. Released 2nd edition of industry authored Introduction to Biomanufacturing textbook, December 2015.
  2. Downstream Processing virtual training module developed in collaboration with industry partners GlaxoSmithKline and Biogenidec http://faculty.mc3.edu/downstreamprocessing/story.html
  3. the development of curriculum for the crossover industries of biofuels and regenerative medicine
  4. Updated NBC2 Biomanufacturing Skill Standards
  5. Developed Biomanufacturing Certification Exam (expected January 2017)

 

Professional Development Offerings for Faculty and Teachers Served 415 Educators:

NBC2 continues to provide industry relevant professional development opportunities to college faculty and high school teachers through a range of activities that included:

  1. The annual Community College Program at the Biotechnology Industry Organization (BIO) International Meeting in Chicago, IL in 2013, San Diego, CA in 2014 and Philadelphia, PA in 2015 (174 participants)
  2. BIOMAN conferences, the annual NBC2 professional development conference for faculty, at MCCC in Blue Bell, PA in 2013, Salt Lake Community College in 2014 and Ivy Tech Community College in 2015 (135 participants)
  3. Six ‘Protein is Cash’ biomanufacturing workshops in 2013 and 2015 serving 106 High School teachers (and thereby serving approximately 10,600 high school students):

 

Professional Development Offerings for Students

  1. Biomanufacturing Career Fairs for students at Great Bay Community College, 2012, Mount Wachusetts Community College, 2013 and Montgomery County Community College and Quincy College in 2015.
  2. Provided training opportunity for 14 students at Biomanufacturing Boot Camp at the North Carolina State University’s BTEC Center July 2014 and 2015
  3. Facilitated internships for students at local companies or in college – company joint projects
